questions.text: A physician is assessing the body composition of patients using various anthropometric indices. Which of the following indices is defined as height in centimetres divided by the cube root of body weight?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ponderal's index is an anthropometric measure calculated as height in centimetres divided by the cube root of body weight. It provides an alternative method to assess body composition, particularly useful in differentiating individuals of similar height but varying body builds. Understanding different indices helps in accurately evaluating and managing patient health.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, who underwent splenectomy 5 years ago, presents to the clinic after being bitten by a previously vaccinated cat. What is the appropriate antibiotic for preventing infection in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Only observation of the cat is sufficient

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For individuals, particularly those who are asplenic, who have been bitten by an animal, amoxicillin-clavulanate is the recommended antibiotic for infection prophylaxis. Proper wound care, including cleaning and debridement, and ensuring appropriate tetanus and rabies prophylaxis, are also critical components of managing animal bites. Understanding the appropriate use of prophylactic antibiotics can prevent serious complications
  • ➤ For individuals, particularly those who are asplenic, who have been bitten by an animal, amoxicillin-clavulanate is the recommended antibiotic for infection prophylaxis. Proper wound care, including cleaning and debridement, and ensuring appropriate tetanus and rabies prophylaxis, are also critical components of managing animal bites. Understanding the appropriate use of prophylactic antibiotics can prevent serious complications

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency room following a road traffic accident with severe pelvic injuries and signs of ongoing hemorrhage. He is hemodynamically unstable and the surgical team is preparing for immediate intervention. Regarding damage control resuscitation in this context, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Blood products should be used to correct coagulopathy.

options.label: B
options.text: Crystalloids and colloids should be used judiciously.

options.label: C
options.text: Systolic blood pressure should be maintained above 100 mm Hg.

options.label: D
options.text: Damage control surgery is employed to control hemorrhage.

questions.correct_answer: C. Systolic blood pressure should be maintained above 100 mm Hg.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In damage control resuscitation, maintaining a lower threshold of systolic blood pressure (70-90 mm Hg) through permissive hypotension is crucial to minimize ongoing hemorrhage while ensuring adequate organ perfusion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman undergoing treatment for leprosy presents with symptoms of Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), a severe inflammatory reaction. What is the appropriate management strategy in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Discontinue anti-leprosy medication and initiate steroids and antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: Continue anti-leprosy medication and add steroids

questions.correct_answer: D. Continue anti-leprosy medication and add steroids
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For managing Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) in pregnant women, it is essential to continue anti-leprosy medications and add steroids to control the inflammatory response. Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects. Ensuring appropriate treatment helps manage the condition effectively while safeguarding maternal and fetal health.
  • ➤ For managing Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) in pregnant women, it is essential to continue anti-leprosy medications and add steroids to control the inflammatory response.
  • ➤ Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects. Ensuring appropriate treatment helps manage the condition effectively while safeguarding maternal and fetal health.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a history of chronic diarrhea, a symmetric dermatitis in sun-exposed areas, and cognitive disturbances suggestive of dementia. Laboratory tests confirm a vitamin deficiency. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this triad of symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pellagra occurs due to Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency Pellagra is characterized by 4 D’s: Diarrhoea, Dermatitis, Dementia, Death
  • ➤ Pellagra occurs due to Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency
  • ➤ Pellagra is characterized by 4 D’s: Diarrhoea, Dermatitis, Dementia, Death

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is in the third stage of labor, and the placenta is about to be delivered. Which statement is incorrect regarding Duncan's placental separation?
questions.correct_answer: C. Most common method of separation
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Duncan's placental separation involves peripheral separation, the maternal surface presenting at the vulva, and more blood loss. It is not the most common method of placental separation; the Schultze method is more common.
  • ➤ Duncan's placental separation involves peripheral separation, the maternal surface presenting at the vulva, and more blood loss.
  • ➤ It is not the most common method of placental separation; the Schultze method is more common.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the hospital with symptoms of bacterial meningitis. Cultures reveal infection with beta-lactamase producing Haemophilus influenzae. Why is cefotaxime preferred over ampicillin in this case?

options.label: B
options.text: Cefotaxime is more effective against H. influenzae with altered penicillin-binding proteins

options.label: C
options.text: Cefotaxime is a bactericidal drug whereas ampicillin is bacteriostatic

options.label: D
options.text: Cefotaxime is more effective against beta-lactamase producing strains

questions.correct_answer: D. Cefotaxime is more effective against beta-lactamase producing strains
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cefotaxime is preferred for treating bacterial meningitis caused by beta-lactamase producing Haemophilus influenzae due to its resistance to beta-lactamase enzymes, ensuring greater efficacy in these cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is prescribed a regimen that includes rifampicin as part of her treatment for tuberculosis. She is currently using combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception. The healthcare provider recommends adding a barrier method of contraception. What is the primary reason for this recommendation?

options.label: A
options.text: Rifampicin reduces the effectiveness of OCPs by inducing their metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: Rifampicin increases the effectiveness of OCPs

options.label: C
options.text: OCPs enhance the effectiveness of rifampicin

options.label: D
options.text: OCPs reduce the effectiveness of rifampicin

questions.correct_answer: A. Rifampicin reduces the effectiveness of OCPs by inducing their metabolism
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rifampicin, used in the treatment of tuberculosis, induces the metabolism of combined oral contraceptive pills, leading to decreased contraceptive effectiveness. To prevent unintended pregnancies, it is recommended to use an additional barrier method of contraception while taking rifampicin.
  • ➤ Rifampicin, used in the treatment of tuberculosis, induces the metabolism of combined oral contraceptive pills, leading to decreased contraceptive effectiveness.
  • ➤ To prevent unintended pregnancies, it is recommended to use an additional barrier method of contraception while taking rifampicin.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and fatigue after returning from a camping trip in a wooded area. The physician suspects babesiosis. Babesiosis is most commonly transmitted by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ticks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Babesiosis is most commonly transmitted by deer tick (hard tick) Ixodes scapularis.
  • ➤ Babesiosis is most commonly transmitted by deer tick (hard tick) Ixodes scapularis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with diabetes insipidus is prescribed a diuretic that paradoxically reduces urine output. Which of the following diuretics shows paradoxical antidiuretic activity in diabetes insipidus?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Thiazide diuretics exhibit paradoxical antidiuretic activity in diabetes insipidus by promoting sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubule, thereby reducing urine output and helping to concentrate the urine.
  • ➤ Thiazide diuretics exhibit paradoxical antidiuretic activity in diabetes insipidus by promoting sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubule, thereby reducing urine output and helping to concentrate the urine.

questions.text: During a ward round, a 42-year-old patient is being discussed due to concerns about dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. The professor explains the role of the countercurrent system in the kidneys in maintaining water and solute balance to the medical interns. Which of the following will function as the countercurrent exchanger in the countercurrent system of the kidneys?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vasa recta function as the counter current exchangers in the kidneys, maintaining the osmotic gradient necessary for the concentration of urine and the regulation of water and solute balance.

questions.text: A forensic expert examines an individual found deceased under suspicious circumstances with a notable skin injury on the forearm as shown in the image. which type of abrasion is most likely observed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pressure abrasion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pressure abrasion results from the direct, intense pressure of a rough object against the skin, often seen in forensic cases involving strangulation or other forms of physical restraint. Recognizing this type of abrasion is crucial for understanding the mechanism of injury and potential circumstances surrounding the individual's death.
  • ➤ Pressure abrasion results from the direct, intense pressure of a rough object against the skin, often seen in forensic cases involving strangulation or other forms of physical restraint.
  • ➤ Recognizing this type of abrasion is crucial for understanding the mechanism of injury and potential circumstances surrounding the individual's death.

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased serum amyloid A production

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic seeking advice on contraceptive options following unprotected intercourse. She is looking to understand which methods are available and effective. Which of the following is NOT considered a post-coital contraceptive?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Emergency contraception (EC) methods are crucial after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy. Key options include the Yuzpe method using combined oral contraceptive pills within 72 hours, and Progesterone Only Pills (POP) which are more effective and have fewer side effects. IUDs can be inserted within 5 days, offering higher efficacy than OCPs. Mifepristone (RU-486) and high-dose estrogens are also available, each with specific usage timelines. Common side effects include nausea, and EC does not protect against STDs.
  • ➤ Emergency contraception (EC) methods are crucial after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy.
  • ➤ Key options include the Yuzpe method using combined oral contraceptive pills within 72 hours, and Progesterone Only Pills (POP) which are more effective and have fewer side effects.
  • ➤ IUDs can be inserted within 5 days, offering higher efficacy than OCPs. Mifepristone (RU-486) and high-dose estrogens are also available, each with specific usage timelines. Common side effects include nausea, and EC does not protect against STDs.

questions.text: A 58-year-old fair skinned male presents to the clinic with a slowly enlarging lesion on his face. Biopsy of the lesion reveals a picture as given below. Given these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing as a pearly lesion with telangiectasia. It grows slowly and is generally considered locally invasive without substantial risk of metastasis. Key histopathological features include basaloid cells with peripheral palisading and occasional central necrosis.
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing as a pearly lesion with telangiectasia.
  • ➤ It grows slowly and is generally considered locally invasive without substantial risk of metastasis. Key histopathological features include basaloid cells with peripheral palisading and occasional central necrosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a major road accident. He is stabilized but exhibits abdominal bruising. A contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) of the abdomen reveals a zone 1 retroperitoneal hematoma, suspected to involve the abdominal aorta. Which surgical maneuver is primarily used to expose the abdominal aorta in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans.B) Mattox

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The Mattox maneuver is crucial for exposing the abdominal aorta in trauma cases, involving medial mobilization of the left colon and spleen. It is a fundamental technique in the management of abdominal vascular injuries, especially in settings of trauma with suspected aortic involvement.
  • ➤ The Mattox maneuver is crucial for exposing the abdominal aorta in trauma cases, involving medial mobilization of the left colon and spleen.
  • ➤ It is a fundamental technique in the management of abdominal vascular injuries, especially in settings of trauma with suspected aortic involvement.

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing the components of disaster management to ensure comprehensive preparation and response plans are in place. Which of the following is not typically practiced in disaster management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Disaster management typically includes triage, rehabilitation, and disaster response. Mass vaccination, while important for controlling infectious diseases, is not a standard component of disaster management. Understanding the various elements of disaster management helps in preparing and implementing effective response plans to minimize the impact of disasters on affected populations. WHO does not recommend routine vaccines viz. Typhoid, Cholera and Tetanus Toxoid vaccinations in routine use in endemic areas post-disaster.
  • ➤ Disaster management typically includes triage, rehabilitation, and disaster response. Mass vaccination, while important for controlling infectious diseases, is not a standard component of disaster management. Understanding the various elements of disaster management helps in preparing and implementing effective response plans to minimize the impact of disasters on affected populations.
  • ➤ WHO does not recommend routine vaccines viz. Typhoid, Cholera and Tetanus Toxoid vaccinations in routine use in endemic areas post-disaster.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does not differentiate a Gartner’s cyst from a cystocele?

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of rugosities of overlying vaginal mucosa

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of rugosities of overlying vaginal mucosa
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Presence of rugosities of overlying vaginal mucosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gartner's cyst can be differentiated from a cystocele by its non-reducible nature and lack of impulse on coughing. The presence of rugosities of the overlying vaginal mucosa is not a differentiating feature.
  • ➤ Gartner's cyst can be differentiated from a cystocele by its non-reducible nature and lack of impulse on coughing.
  • ➤ The presence of rugosities of the overlying vaginal mucosa is not a differentiating feature.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is an example of inducing active immunity?

options.label: A
options.text: Administration of toxoids to stimulate antibody production.

options.label: B
options.text: Exposure to a subclinical infection leading to immune response without symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Administration of antitoxin to neutralize toxins.

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of immunoglobulins for immediate protection.

questions.correct_answer: A. Administration of toxoids to stimulate antibody production.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Administration of toxoids to stimulate antibody production.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Active immunity is induced by methods that stimulate the body's immune system to produce its own antibodies, such as the administration of toxoids or exposure to an infection.
  • ➤ Active immunity is induced by methods that stimulate the body's immune system to produce its own antibodies, such as the administration of toxoids or exposure to an infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman with type 2 diabetes and primary hypertension presents with severe abdominal pain and scleral icterus. Blood pressure is 126/82 mm/Hg, and blood glucose is 98 mg/dL. Ultrasound reveals decreased hepatic vein flow. What most likely predisposes her to this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is characterized by reduced hepatic outflow, with risk factors including pregnancy, oral contraceptives, and hypercoagulable states.
  • ➤ Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is characterized by reduced hepatic outflow, with risk factors including pregnancy, oral contraceptives, and hypercoagulable states.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man, who was recently found to have renal vein thrombosis, is under medical review. His medical history includes significant weight gain, generalized edema, and hypertension. His urine analysis reveals significant proteinuria and the presence of numerous normal-looking red blood cells without any casts. Tests also show positive anti-PLA2R antibodies. Based on these findings, what would you expect to see on his renal biopsy?

options.label: A
options.text: Diffuse thickening of the GBM with a spike and dome pattern

questions.correct_answer: A. Diffuse thickening of the GBM with a spike and dome pattern
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome and testing positive for anti-PLA2R antibodies, the expected finding on renal biopsy is a diffuse thickening of the GBM with a spike and dome pattern, indicative of primary membranous nephropathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic asthma presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath and wheezing unresponsive to his usual inhaled salbutamol. The patient is given intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline, which lead to significant improvement. What is the primary mechanism by which corticosteroids help in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: They cause bronchodilation when given with xanthines

options.label: B
options.text: They increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol

options.label: C
options.text: They increase the action of aminophylline on adenosine receptors

questions.correct_answer: B. They increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Corticosteroids enhance the responsiveness of bronchial smooth muscle to beta-agonists like salbutamol by reducing airway inflammation and edema. This leads to improved bronchodilation and symptom relief in acute asthma exacerbations.
  • ➤ Corticosteroids enhance the responsiveness of bronchial smooth muscle to beta-agonists like salbutamol by reducing airway inflammation and edema.
  • ➤ This leads to improved bronchodilation and symptom relief in acute asthma exacerbations.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with dark urine, a history of bacterial infections, and venous thromboses, including portal vein thrombosis. Examination shows a swollen, tender right leg. questions.text: A 41-year-old man presents with increasing dyspnea for the past week. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 37.3°C, pulse 85/min, and blood pressure 150/95 mm Hg. There is dullness to percussion over the lung bases. Laboratory findings include serum creatinine 3.1 mg/dL, urea nitrogen 29 mg/dL, troponin I 0.1 ng/mL, hemoglobin 11.7 g/dL, and positive ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibody test results. questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Libman-Sacks endocarditis

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Positive ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are indicative of SLE, making Libman-Sacks endocarditis the most likely cardiac lesion in this patient.
  • ➤ Libman-Sacks endocarditis is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and presents with nonbacterial vegetations on heart valves.
  • ➤ Positive ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are indicative of SLE, making Libman-Sacks endocarditis the most likely cardiac lesion in this patient.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a high fever, severe sore throat, and difficulty breathing. questions.text: A 38-year-old male chronic alcoholic is admitted to the general medicine ward with symptoms of abdominal distention, yellowish discoloration of the eyes, and abdominal pain. He is diagnosed with decompensated liver disease. All of the following clotting factors will be affected in this patient except:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In decompensated liver disease, the synthesis of most clotting factors, including Factors II, VII, and IX, is impaired due to the liver's compromised function. Factor VIII, however, is less affected because it is primarily produced by endothelial cells, not hepatocytes, and may remain normal or even elevated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with progressive weakness and sensory disturbances. His MRI shows demyelination of the central nervous system. The neurologist explains the concept of saltatory conduction to the residents using this case. Which of the following statements about saltatory conduction is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves the action potential "jumping" from one node of Ranvier to the next

options.label: B
options.text: It is characterized by the repolarization phase "jumping" across myelin sheaths

options.label: C
options.text: It enhances the speed of nerve impulse transmission

options.label: D
options.text: It is a feature of myelinated axons, contributing to efficient neural communication

questions.correct_answer: B. It is characterized by the repolarization phase "jumping" across myelin sheaths
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Saltatory conduction increases the speed and efficiency of nerve impulse transmission by allowing action potentials to jump from one node of Ranvier to the next in myelinated axons. The repolarization phase does not "jump" across myelin sheaths, making that statement incorrect.
  • ➤ Saltatory conduction increases the speed and efficiency of nerve impulse transmission by allowing action potentials to jump from one node of Ranvier to the next in myelinated axons.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is started on a new medication. Initial pharmacokinetic studies suggest that the drug is being stored in the tissues. Which of the following findings would be most indicative of this?
questions.correct_answer: B. Large apparent volume of distribution
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Volume of distribution (Vd) signifies the distribution of drug in the tissues. Low Vd mean less drug is distributed to tissues whereas high value of Vd means drug is being stored in some tissue. A large apparent volume of distribution (Vd) suggests that a drug is extensively distributed into and stored in body tissues rather than remaining in the plasma. Volume of distribution is the hypothetical volume of plasma that would be required to contain the administered dose if that dose was evenly distributed at the concentration measured in plasma. If more amount of drug is entering the tissues, it has a higher volume of distribution and vice-a-versa. It depends on several factors like lipid solubility and plasma protein binding.
  • ➤ Volume of distribution (Vd) signifies the distribution of drug in the tissues.
  • ➤ Low Vd mean less drug is distributed to tissues whereas high value of Vd means drug is being stored in some tissue.
  • ➤ A large apparent volume of distribution (Vd) suggests that a drug is extensively distributed into and stored in body tissues rather than remaining in the plasma.
  • ➤ Volume of distribution is the hypothetical volume of plasma that would be required to contain the administered dose if that dose was evenly distributed at the concentration measured in plasma.
  • ➤ If more amount of drug is entering the tissues, it has a higher volume of distribution and vice-a-versa.
  • ➤ It depends on several factors like lipid solubility and plasma protein binding.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, who has been consuming a diet primarily consisting of Lathyrus sativus (grass pea) due to economic hardship and successive crop failures, presents with progressive weakness in his legs, spasticity, and difficulty walking. questions.explanation:
Ans. A) BOAA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of chronic lower back pain is consulting with her healthcare provider about various pain management strategies. questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of myasthenia gravis presents with worsening muscle weakness. To differentiate between a myasthenic crisis and a cholinergic crisis, which of the following drugs should be used?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Edrophonium is preferred for differentiating between myasthenic crisis and cholinergic crisis due to its short duration of action. It increases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, improving symptoms in myasthenic crisis and worsening them in cholinergic crisis, thus aiding in the accurate diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a large, mobile mass in her breast. She reports the mass has been growing rapidly but is not painful. After a biopsy, she is diagnosed with a phyllodes tumor. Based on the information provided, which of the following statements about phyllodes tumors is FALSE?

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment options include wide local excision or simple mastectomy.

options.label: C
options.text: Axillary clearance is not typically required for phyllodes tumors.

options.label: D
options.text: Phyllodes tumors can present with a bosselated surface and overlying ulceration.

questions.correct_answer: A. Phyllodes tumors are always benign.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phyllodes tumors are always benign.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Phyllodes tumors of the breast can range from benign to malignant and do not always necessitate axillary lymph node dissection unless there is clinical or pathological evidence of metastasis. Management usually involves surgical resection with an emphasis on obtaining clear margins to reduce recurrence rates.
  • ➤ Phyllodes tumors of the breast can range from benign to malignant and do not always necessitate axillary lymph node dissection unless there is clinical or pathological evidence of metastasis.
  • ➤ Management usually involves surgical resection with an emphasis on obtaining clear margins to reduce recurrence rates.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a 10-day history of abdominal pain, dark urine, and purpuric skin lesions. Urinalysis shows hematuria and proteinuria. Serologic tests are negative for P-ANCAs and C-ANCAs. Skin biopsy reveals necrotizing vasculitis of small dermal vessels, and renal biopsy shows IgA-rich immune complex deposition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Henoch-Schönlein purpura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by IgA deposition, presenting with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and renal involvement, making it the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.
